Title.evidence: Preoperative Enema in Anal Surgery: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either a preoperative enema (n=133) or no enema (n=133).

Participants.evidence: Conducted at Taipei Medical University Shuang-Ho Hospital, Taiwan, from November 2022 to August 2023, the study enrolled adults aged 20–85 years with grade III or IV haemorrhoids or anal fistulas.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either a preoperative enema (n=133) or no enema (n=133).

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed the efficacy of preoperative enemas in reducing postoperative pain and complications in anal surgeries.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative pain measured by the visual analogue scale (VAS) from day 0 to day 7.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Surgeons and data analysts were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either a preoperative enema (n=133) or no enema (n=133).

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 266 patients analysed, no significant differences were observed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Subgroup analysis revealed no significant differences for stapled haemorrhoidopexy and anal fistula surgeries.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events related to enemas were reported.
